document_metadata.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Lifestyle and environmental factors are established contributors to risk for MS.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Lifestyle and environmental factors are established contributors to risk for MS.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Lifestyle and environmental factors are established contributors to risk for MS.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: There is a positive association between latitude and prevalence of MS at a global level, unexplained by the genetic distribution of high-risk alleles (12).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Early work has shown that duration of exposure to sunlight and sunlight intensity are associated with MS risk

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Early work has shown that duration of exposure to sunlight and sunlight intensity are associated with MS risk

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Several studies have assessed the role of vitamin D deficiency in the perinatal period (by utilization of biobanks and dried blood spot samples) upon risk for MS, with conflicting results. Swedish studies have looked at the relationship of 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels during gestation (25) and in the neonatal period (26) as it relates to risk of developing MS in these offspring.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Lower neonatal vitamin D levels were associated with a higher MS risk, with every 25 nmol/L increase in 25-hydroxyvitamin D conferring a 30% reduced risk for MS (27).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: The seroprevalence rates of remote EBV infection are higher in MS as compared to healthy controls, in both adult (31) and pediatric MS patients; however, this association is more striking when studied in the pediatric MS population given the lower rate of seroprevalence in healthy children and adolescents (32,33).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: A role for human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) has been suggested from studies demonstrating elevated antibodies against HHV-6 in serum of MS patients in addition to the detection of viral DNA within the plaques of MS patients (38).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: A role for human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) has been suggested from studies demonstrating elevated antibodies against HHV-6 in serum of MS patients in addition to the detection of viral DNA within the plaques of MS patients (38).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Deeper investigation revealed these to be part of an HLA haplotype â in particular, the HLA-DRB1*15:01 allele has consistently been shown to be an independent risk factor for MS, particularly in populations of European ancestry, with an odds ratio (OR) of approximately 3 (75).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Given this, there has been exploration into the idea that genetic variants within the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) could play a role in MS risk. Mitochondrial haplogroups have been associated with adult-onset MS (82).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Children with HLADRB1*15 alleles were more likely to ultimately meet diagnostic criteria for MS (OR=2.7). This effect was greater in children of European ancestry (OR=3.3). No difference in DRB1*15 allele frequency was found between children with monophasic acute demyelinating syndrome and unaffected controls (84), suggesting that the HLA-DRB1*15 allele is a risk factor for pediatric MS but not monophasic demyelinating events (23).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Along with the potential for accumulating physical disability, symptoms of co-morbid depression (125), fatigue (125), reduced physical activity (126,127), and cognitive dysfunction (128-130) are also highly prevalent.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Along with the potential for accumulating physical disability, symptoms of co-morbid depression (125), fatigue (125), reduced physical activity (126,127), and cognitive dysfunction (128-130) are also highly prevalent.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Lifestyle and environmental factors are established contributors to risk for MS.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: There is a positive association between latitude and prevalence of MS at a global level, unexplained by the genetic distribution of high-risk alleles (12).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Early work has shown that duration of exposure to sunlight and sunlight intensity are associated with MS risk

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Furthermore, both outdoor work and residence in a high sunlight area have been associated with lower MS mortality rates (17).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Early work has shown that duration of exposure to sunlight and sunlight intensity are associated with MS risk

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Furthermore, both outdoor work and residence in a high sunlight area have been associated with lower MS mortality rates (17).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Work in the experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE) mouse model has shown beneficial effects of UVR exposure on EAE disease, independent of vitamin D status (20).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: The results demonstrated a significant decrease in risk of MS associated with increasing 25-hydroxyvitamin D among whites.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Several studies have assessed the role of vitamin D deficiency in the perinatal period (by utilization of biobanks and dried blood spot samples) upon risk for MS, with conflicting results. Swedish studies have looked at the relationship of 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels during gestation (25) and in the neonatal period (26) as it relates to risk of developing MS in these offspring.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Lower neonatal vitamin D levels were associated with a higher MS risk, with every 25 nmol/L increase in 25-hydroxyvitamin D conferring a 30% reduced risk for MS (27).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: In addition, low vitamin D levels have been implicated in risk for pediatric MS (23) and the prevalence and degree of low vitamin D are comparable between adult and pediatric MS patients (24).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Lower neonatal vitamin D levels were associated with a higher MS risk, with every 25 nmol/L increase in 25-hydroxyvitamin D conferring a 30% reduced risk for MS (27).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: MS disease-modifying therapies and vitamin D supplementation have a modulatory effect on the human gut microbial composition (62).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: In addition, low vitamin D levels have been implicated in risk for pediatric MS (23) and the prevalence and degree of low vitamin D are comparable between adult and pediatric MS patients (24).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: The seroprevalence rates of remote EBV infection are higher in MS as compared to healthy controls, in both adult (31) and pediatric MS patients; however, this association is more striking when studied in the pediatric MS population given the lower rate of seroprevalence in healthy children and adolescents (32,33).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Indeed, pediatric MS case-control studies have demonstrated differences in gut flora (at a taxa-level) between cohorts(61).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: In pediatric MS cohorts, HLA-DRB1 is associated with the EBNA-1 antibody response, suggesting that HLA risk genes have an important influence on the immune response to viral infection (99).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Along with the potential for accumulating physical disability, symptoms of co-morbid depression (125), fatigue (125), reduced physical activity (126,127), and cognitive dysfunction (128-130) are also highly prevalent.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Evidence suggests that a pediatric MS patientâs antibody response to remote EBV is modified by the HLA-DRB1 allele (35)

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Remote cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, denoted by the presence of positive serologic anti-CMV IgG, appears to be protective against pediatric MS diagnosis (OR of 0.27; 95% CI 0.11-0.67) (36).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Remote cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, denoted by the presence of positive serologic anti-CMV IgG, appears to be protective against pediatric MS diagnosis (OR of 0.27; 95% CI 0.11-0.67) (36).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Remote cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, denoted by the presence of positive serologic anti-CMV IgG, appears to be protective against pediatric MS diagnosis (OR of 0.27; 95% CI 0.11-0.67) (36).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: A role for human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) has been suggested from studies demonstrating elevated antibodies against HHV-6 in serum of MS patients in addition to the detection of viral DNA within the plaques of MS patients (38).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Smoking has been shown to increase risk of MS; furthermore, risk increases in a dose-dependent fashion with higher cumulative smoking dose.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Smoking has also been shown to increase the risk of MS disability progression (41).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Despite this, oral tobacco use has not been associated with elevated risk for MS, which suggests that nicotine is not the responsible agent (39).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Despite this, oral tobacco use has not been associated with elevated risk for MS, which suggests that nicotine is not the responsible agent (39).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: The frequency of exposure to parental passive smoking was associated with an increased risk for MS (RR 2.12, 95% CI 1.43-3.15).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Along with the potential for accumulating physical disability, symptoms of co-morbid depression (125), fatigue (125), reduced physical activity (126,127), and cognitive dysfunction (128-130) are also highly prevalent.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Following this, it was demonstrated that childhood obesity is independently associated with an increased risk of pediatric MS and CIS in girls (but not boys).This risk appears to be dose dependent as well, with higher weight categories being associated with a higher risk (50).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Following this, it was demonstrated that childhood obesity is independently associated with an increased risk of pediatric MS and CIS in girls (but not boys).This risk appears to be dose dependent as well, with higher weight categories being associated with a higher risk (50).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: A more recent study has demonstrated that a higher body mass index (BMI) in early adolescence is a risk factor for pediatric MS in post-pubertal girls (OR=1.60, 95% CI: 1.12-2.27) and boys (OR=1.43, 95% CI: 1.08-1.88) (51).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Though human studies are confounded due to reliance on patient recollection and nonspecific survey-based questionnaires, high salt diet has been shown in EAE models to increase risk of autoimmune disease and drive severity of EAE due to induction of pathogenic TH17 cells (52).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Though human studies are confounded due to reliance on patient recollection and nonspecific survey-based questionnaires, high salt diet has been shown in EAE models to increase risk of autoimmune disease and drive severity of EAE due to induction of pathogenic TH17 cells (52).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: The bacterial milieu within the gastrointestinal tract has a substantial influence on an individualâs immune profile and response â including development of the immune system, protection against pathogens, and maintenance of immune response (57).

links.evidence: The bacterial milieu within the gastrointestinal tract has a substantial influence on an individualâs immune profile and response â including development of the immune system, protection against pathogens, and maintenance of immune response (57).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: In pediatric MS cohorts, HLA-DRB1 is associated with the EBNA-1 antibody response, suggesting that HLA risk genes have an important influence on the immune response to viral infection (99).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: To-date, taking into account the entire human genome, the MHC, located on chromosome 6, comprises the single largest genetic contribution to MS susceptibility. HLA genes encode for cell surface glycoproteins with a primary role in presenting antigenic peptide fragments to T-cells (74)

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: In pediatric MS cohorts, HLA-DRB1 is associated with the EBNA-1 antibody response, suggesting that HLA risk genes have an important influence on the immune response to viral infection (99).

links.evidence: To-date, taking into account the entire human genome, the MHC, located on chromosome 6, comprises the single largest genetic contribution to MS susceptibility. HLA genes encode for cell surface glycoproteins with a primary role in presenting antigenic peptide fragments to T-cells (74)

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: To-date, taking into account the entire human genome, the MHC, located on chromosome 6, comprises the single largest genetic contribution to MS susceptibility. HLA genes encode for cell surface glycoproteins with a primary role in presenting antigenic peptide fragments to T-cells (74)

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Deeper investigation revealed these to be part of an HLA haplotype â in particular, the HLA-DRB1*15:01 allele has consistently been shown to be an independent risk factor for MS, particularly in populations of European ancestry, with an odds ratio (OR) of approximately 3 (75).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: the HLA-DRB1*15:03 allele is a risk factor in African Americans, while the HLA-A*02 allele appears to confer a protective effect against MS, with an OR of approximately 0.6 (79).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: the HLA-DRB1*15:03 allele is a risk factor in African Americans, while the HLA-A*02 allele appears to confer a protective effect against MS, with an OR of approximately 0.6 (79).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Given this, there has been exploration into the idea that genetic variants within the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) could play a role in MS risk. Mitochondrial haplogroups have been associated with adult-onset MS (82).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Many of the currently-identified haplogroups have SNPs that occur in genes that encode subunits of the oxidative phosphorylation complex - deficiencies of which can result in bioenergetic dysfunction.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Many of the currently-identified haplogroups have SNPs that occur in genes that encode subunits of the oxidative phosphorylation complex - deficiencies of which can result in bioenergetic dysfunction.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Children with HLADRB1*15 alleles were more likely to ultimately meet diagnostic criteria for MS (OR=2.7). This effect was greater in children of European ancestry (OR=3.3). No difference in DRB1*15 allele frequency was found between children with monophasic acute demyelinating syndrome and unaffected controls (84), suggesting that the HLA-DRB1*15 allele is a risk factor for pediatric MS but not monophasic demyelinating events (23).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Children with HLADRB1*15 alleles were more likely to ultimately meet diagnostic criteria for MS (OR=2.7). This effect was greater in children of European ancestry (OR=3.3). No difference in DRB1*15 allele frequency was found between children with monophasic acute demyelinating syndrome and unaffected controls (84), suggesting that the HLA-DRB1*15 allele is a risk factor for pediatric MS but not monophasic demyelinating events (23).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Smoking greatly increases MS risk in individuals who are positive for the HLA-DRB1*15 allele and negative for the HLA-A*02 allele (OR 13.5) compared to nonsmokers with the same HLA genotype (OR 4.9) (101)

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Obesity has been linked to HLA risk alleles, as obese (BMIâ¥27) individuals, who were positive for HLADRB1* 15 and negative for HLA-A*02 exhibited an increased risk of MS (OR 16.2) compared to those with BMI < 27 with the same HLA genotype risk factors (OR 5.1) (103).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Children with HLADRB1*15 alleles were more likely to ultimately meet diagnostic criteria for MS (OR=2.7). This effect was greater in children of European ancestry (OR=3.3). No difference in DRB1*15 allele frequency was found between children with monophasic acute demyelinating syndrome and unaffected controls (84), suggesting that the HLA-DRB1*15 allele is a risk factor for pediatric MS but not monophasic demyelinating events (23).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Studies have identified tissue-specific (e.g. within the CNS white matter of MS patients) upregulation of the peptidylargininedeiminase-2 (PAD2) enzyme by way of DNA hypomethylation.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: This upregulation of PAD2 leads to production of a less-stable form of myelin basic protein and subsequent loss of immune tolerance (89).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: epigenetic research in MS patients have demonstrated evidence of hypomethylation of genes involved in regulation of immune response and T-cell differentiation âincluding IFNG, FOXP3, IL-13 and IL-17 (91) â ultimately resulting in increased expression of these genes.

links.evidence: Other studies have demonstrated evidence of hypermethylation in genes involved with immune system regulation (e.g. SHP-1), resulting in reduced genetic expression and a resultant increase in leukocyte-mediated inflammation (92).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: It also appears that viral infections may help to shape the early immune response, as early life herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV-1) infection appears to be protective in those who are HLA-DRB1*15 positive (100).

citation.name: Pediatric Multiple Sclerosis: Genes, Environment, and a Comprehensive Therapeutic Approach.

links.evidence: Oral agents (i.e. fingolimod, teriflunomide, dimethyl fumarate) have been approved for relapsing adult MS, and many pediatric patients exhibit a desire for these therapies given the route of administration.
